story:
About Us

Cadence Please Missions was born in the late summer of 2013 when a group of young believers decided to live a radical lifestyle, leaving their homes and relying fully on Jesus to sustain them. It started with a simple conviction: if Jesus lived not to be served but to serve others (Mark 10:45), shouldn’t his disciples model that behavior? A focal point of our service has always been through music—from Sunday morning worship to youth groups to recovery groups to summer camps we have led worship across the country. Often, however, we serve in ways that have nothing to do with music. In the past two years we have cleaned gutters, mowed lawns, roofed buildings, painted rooms, and even assisted in flood, tornado, and fire relief efforts. We have served in over a dozen states in the past two years:

As our ministry has grown, so too has our vision. We began to see the potential for our ministry model to fill needs in other countries as well as our own. In particular, there is a massive need for children’s housing and education in many third-world nations. After seeing this need firsthand, Cadence Please Missions committed to doing something to help.

December 30th we will begin building what we call a “Cadence Cottage” — a combination orphanage and Children’s Center, which will provide services for underprivileged children and housing for children who are currently living on the streets.


Our Vision

James 1:27a "Religion that is pure and undefiled before God, the Father, is this: to visit orphans and widows in their affliction..."

Our first Cadence Cottage will be planted in Nueva Gorgona, Panama.

We are working with established churches and Panamanian residents, in particular a Christian couple who have dedicated their property for the specific purpose of building a Cadence Cottage. 

In the Children's Center, there will be a tutoring lounge, game room, computer lab, and a feeding program. This meets a vital need in a community where children are otherwise unable to have these things. 

In the orphanage, our goal is to house some of the children we'll meet through the children's center. Our desire is to provide not only food and shelter (which are important), but a real home. We desire to give these kids a family. The Cadence Cottage is a place where children can be educated, loved, and know that God places the lonely in families (Psalm 68:6).

We will use an identical model to build the second Cadence Cottage in the Dominican Republic.

You might be wondering why we haven’t moved forward in the Dominican Republic, and why the sudden shift to Panama. Simply put, the opportunity we were looking for in the Dominican Republic ended up coming to us sooner in Panama. We haven’t touched the funds we’ve raised for the D.R, as we still plan to build there as soon as we have a place to build.


Our Goal 

Our heart is that each of these Cadence Cottages would meet a variety of material needs in the community, and it will cost a considerable amount of money to achieve this. What we’re looking at is $100,000 to fund the first two Cadence Cottages, which is no small number! Here is a breakdown of where the money will be going:

Panama and Dominican Republic Goal - $100,000

Panama Needs ($70,000):                         D.R. Needs ($30,000):

Food & Transportation: $6,000                      Food & Transportation: $6,000

Children’s Center: $30,000                             Children’s Center: Funds Raised

Apartments (Casitas): $10,000                      Apartments (Casitas): Funds Raised

15 Passenger Van: $15,000                              15 Passenger Van: $15,000

Supplies for Center: $9,000                            Supplies for Center: $9,000


The Impact

By contributing financially to the completion of this project, you are actually:

      (1) Providing Hope by removing endangered children from otherwise bleak realities.

      (2) Breathing Life into these children by exposing them to the love of Christ, the stability of a family, and the Word of God on a daily basis.


Other Ways You Can Help

Clearly, a $100,000 building project in a third-world country is no frivolous endeavor, and we take it very seriously. We can’t reach our goal without the support of others, and you can help in a variety of ways:

1.  Donate. Help fund a home for children who don’t have one. The reality is this... There's not guarantee these children will be around another year if we don't do something to help now. Your immediate sacrifice has the power to save lives both physically and spiritually.

2.  Pray. We believe that prayer is a crucial part of success, and in all that we do we want to be dedicated to praying for it. There are many unknown risks and challenges we will face during this process, and the prayer support of our brothers and sisters is vital if we are going to make this happen.

3.  Go. We have multiple teams from churches across the U.S. flying out to build with us, but we can always use more help. If you are interested in a short-term mission trip during this building process, let us know! It's not too late.

4.  SHARE! You may not be able to help in any of the above ways, but you can spread the word! Share this page and get the word out to your friends!

#CadenceCottage2016
story_txt:
About Us

Cadence Please Missions was born in the late summer of 2013 when a group of young believers decided to live a radical lifestyle, leaving their homes and relying fully on Jesus to sustain them. It started with a simple conviction: if Jesus lived not to be served but to serve others (Mark 10:45), shouldn’t his disciples model that behavior? A focal point of our service has always been through music—from Sunday morning worship to youth groups to recovery groups to summer camps we have led worship across the country. Often, however, we serve in ways that have nothing to do with music. In the past two years we have cleaned gutters, mowed lawns, roofed buildings, painted rooms, and even assisted in flood, tornado, and fire relief efforts. We have served in over a dozen states in the past two years:


As our ministry has grown, so too has our vision. We began to see the potential for our ministry model to fill needs in other countries as well as our own. In particular, there is a massive need for children’s housing and education in many third-world nations. After seeing this need firsthand, Cadence Please Missions committed to doing something to help.
December 30th we will begin building what we call a “Cadence Cottage” — a combination orphanage and Children’s Center, which will provide services for underprivileged children and housing for children who are currently living on the streets.Our Vision 
James 1:27a "Religion that is pure and undefiled before God, the Father, is this: to visit orphans and widows in their affliction..."
Our first Cadence Cottage will be planted in Nueva Gorgona, Panama.


We are working with established churches and Panamanian residents, in particular a Christian couple who have dedicated their property for the specific purpose of building a Cadence Cottage. In the Children's Center, there will be a tutoring lounge, game room, computer lab, and a feeding program. This meets a vital need in a community where children are otherwise unable to have these things. In the orphanage, our goal is to house some of the children we'll meet through the children's center. Our desire is to provide not only food and shelter (which are important), but a real home. We desire to give these kids a family. The Cadence Cottage is a place where children can be educated, loved, and know that God places the lonely in families (Psalm 68:6).
We will use an identical model to build the second Cadence Cottage in the Dominican Republic.
You might be wondering why we haven’t moved forward in the Dominican Republic, and why the sudden shift to Panama. Simply put, the opportunity we were looking for in the Dominican Republic ended up coming to us sooner in Panama. We haven’t touched the funds we’ve raised for the D.R, as we still plan to build there as soon as we have a place to build.

Our Goal 
Our heart is that each of these Cadence Cottages would meet a variety of material needs in the community, and it will cost a considerable amount of money to achieve this. What we’re looking at is $100,000 to fund the first two Cadence Cottages, which is no small number! Here is a breakdown of where the money will be going:
Panama and Dominican Republic Goal - $100,000
Panama Needs ($70,000):                         D.R. Needs ($30,000):
Food & Transportation: $6,000                      Food & Transportation: $6,000
Children’s Center: $30,000                             Children’s Center: Funds Raised

Apartments (Casitas): $10,000                      Apartments (Casitas): Funds Raised

15 Passenger Van: $15,000                              15 Passenger Van: $15,000
Supplies for Center: $9,000                            Supplies for Center: $9,000


The Impact
By contributing financially to the completion of this project, you are actually:
      (1) Providing Hope by removing endangered children from otherwise bleak realities.      (2) Breathing Life into these children by exposing them to the love of Christ, the stability of a family, and the Word of God on a daily basis.


    Other Ways You Can Help 
Clearly, a $100,000 building project in a third-world country is no frivolous endeavor, and we take it very seriously. We can’t reach our goal without the support of others, and you can help in a variety of ways:1.  Donate. Help fund a home for children who don’t have one. The reality is this... There's not guarantee these children will be around another year if we don't do something to help now. Your immediate sacrifice has the power to save lives both physically and spiritually.
2.  Pray. We believe that prayer is a crucial part of success, and in all that we do we want to be dedicated to praying for it. There are many unknown risks and challenges we will face during this process, and the prayer support of our brothers and sisters is vital if we are going to make this happen.
3.  Go. We have multiple teams from churches across the U.S. flying out to build with us, but we can always use more help. If you are interested in a short-term mission trip during this building process, let us know! It's not too late.
4.  SHARE! You may not be able to help in any of the above ways, but you can spread the word! Share this page and get the word out to your friends!#CadenceCottage2016

story:
Who we are and what we do 

In an era where electronic devices rule. We have seen a decline in creativity and recreational reading. This decline has lead to a decrease in the academic levels among youths. Our goal is to bring recreational reading back through comics and other fun traditional mediums. We are going to be hosting events such as comic conventions and free comic book days where children will be encouraged to meet the creators to encourage their own passion for reading and the arts. 

Our Organization is comprised of veteran educator, comic book creators, marketing & advertising individuals and college students and volunteers.

We can use your help! Our Immediate funding needs are for initial licensing and promotional materials as well as our first free comic book day event. We have locations and sponsors set but need initial funding to get us started. We are offering some really cool art and comics donated by our comic creator supporters as rewards for our supporters.


What We Need & What You Get

We need $2000.00 to finish our non-profit licensing process

$850 for federal tax exemption application

$250 for state exemption

$60 G-60 filing

$25 DCCA registration

$400 Legal fees

$ 200-400 Charter creation and Design costs

Perks and Rewards

We have custom sketches by famous artists Rusty Gilligan, Bryan Makana Revell, Chris Carvahlo and much more. Including comics and other great rewards.

The Impact

We will bring recreational learning back to our youth through comics, graphic novels, prose, poetry and much more. Creating a fun and conducive learning environment for our future generations to create and enjoy reading.

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest challenge is funding as we are not a 501c yet. However we believe in our cause and so do many others. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign as well as our website at www.lthruc.com where you can donate at anytime and encourage others to do the same. Much thanks and appreciation.

story:
Personalized learning that engages, excites and empowers

What if every student was able to personalize their learning through technology? What if every student could feel engaged, excited, and empowered to learn? Our Ednexio learning platform uses technology to personalize learning and, ultimately, empowers students to learn at their own pace, excites students to continue to learn more, and engages students by allowing them to learn how they learn best. 

What's different about the Ednexio learning platform?  
Teachers know what students need to learn and students know how they want to learn it.  Ednexio provides the structure for successful collaborative and personalized learning . Teachers create and share engaging lessons enhanced with technology that motivate students to learn.  But it doesn't stop there!  Ednexio creates a learning environment that mirrors the real world.  It provides the framework for students to apply what they've learned, work collaboratively with others,  and develop solutions to real life problems. 

View our learning platform from the student's perspective



What do kids think about using technology to learn? 

Here's what Ethan, Nicholas, Jack, and Lucy have to say...

Jack, 8th Grader: " Technology motivates me to get my schoolwork done.  I can't imagine a world without technology.  It's everywhere!"

Nicholas, 8th Grader: "On a scale of 1-10 with 10 being the most important, teaching students to use technology is a 10.  I can't think of any career or job in my future that will not be using technology."

Ethan, 8th Grader: "Schools should let us use technology because the world is using tech more and more every day."

Lucy, 5th Grader: "I don't get to use technology at school.  I have to ask my brother to show me how to use it when I get home."


Do parents think it is important to teach with technology in school? 

Here's what Dom, Lindy and Claire had to say...

Dom: “My job here on Maui requires that I connect with people on the mainland on a daily basis through technology.  It is extremely important to me that my kids learn how to use technology in school so they’ll have the skills to succeed in the real world.”

Lindy: "Technology is the top of the list of important subjects. If you are not teaching technology in the schools where are kids going to learn how to use it?  They are learning from You Tube and social media.  Are they learning the things they really need to know?  I don’t think so.  I would hope it would come from the classroom."

Claire: "In 6th grade, my son worked on a 3-month long Science project and used technology every day.  The students felt they were in charge.  They were creating presentations, videos, doing research and collaborating with each other. It was such a great experience and they used great tools.  Just like in the workforce where people are working in teams, working on projects together.  Teaching these life skills and modeling the real world of work is exactly what schools and teachers need to be having kids do."


Why do we need this money?

Ednexio currently has the framework that allows students to personalize their learning, but we need your help to create high quality, technology infused lessons that will be available for all to use in the Shared Library.  

Teachers currently have the ability to create their own lessons inside Ednexio.  Just imagine if teachers were able to share their ednexio lessons with each other and, beyond that, were able to customize any lesson to fit the needs of their students! Teachers would have instant access to pre-screened lessons for all standards, grades, and subject areas - English Language Arts, Math, Science, History Social Science, Technology, Visual and Performing Arts.  

Students would have access to all of these lessons, without having to wait for their teachers to create every lesson themselves.  Imagine the possibilities if students could benefit from the knowledge and expertise of not only their teacher, but teachers around the world.  Teachers would be able to collaborate and keep their students engaged and excited to learn every day!

We need $100,000 to build 2500 interactive, teacher-created lessons for grades Kindergarten through 8th for our Shared Library.  Your support will help students experience cutting edge, personalized learning at a much faster rate than would otherwise be possible.


Other Ways You Can Help - Spread the Word!

It's time classrooms evolve from a one-size-fits-all model to one of personalized learning enhanced by technology.  Join us in our mission to change the classroom into a place that engages students to learn through technology; a place that excites students and encourages creativity, collaboration and problem-solving; and a place that empowers students by teaching them the skills to succeed now and in the future.  

Whether you contribute to our campaign or not, you can help us by:

  • encouraging teachers and principals you may know to use Ednexio.
  • discussing the benefits of Ednexio for both students and teachers at your next PTC/PTA meeting .
  • urging your school to become innovative and use Ednexio in their classrooms.
  • spreading the word about Ednexio on Facebook, Twitter, email, and through face-to-face conversations.


Perks

We want teachers to have the means to experiment with and use Ednexio on a daily basis.   When a teacher signs up for an Ednexio account, we provide them with "free trial" credits to assign lessons to their students.  Before they spend their credits and assign lessons, they are able to explore all the features of Ednexio. Once they use up their free credits, they must purchase additional credits to continue to assign lessons to their students.   
Our perks allow you to:
  • buy gift coupons for a  student, teacher, or a school you may know.  
  • sponsor a lesson.  Is there something you enjoyed learning when you were in school?  Share your idea with us and we'll create a lesson for the Shared Library.  Your name will appear on the lesson as a sponsor.
  • become a Bronze, Silver or Gold sponsor.  Your name or logo will appear on our website.
  • become an angel sponsor.  You know you want to help personalize learning, but you're not sure what "perk" you want to contribute to.  No worries!  We'll put your angel contribution where it's needed most.  Your name will appear on our website.
  • donate as a "Mover and Shaker."  Your name or company will appear on our website.

story:
The 'Smiles of Cambodia' foundation was created by a group of friends to support KSEDO in Cambodia


Khmer Social Economic Development Organisation (KSEDO) is a non-government, non profit Children’s Centre located in Siem Reip, Cambodia.  Its main mission is to participate in developing and promoting education, agriculture and community projects with sustainability.


The centre was established by a small group on 25 January 2011 and is registered and approved by local authorities in Cambodia. The organisation was registered under the Ministry of Interior of The Kingdom of Cambodia on 27 January 2011 by Siem Reap City Hall Orphanage and Foster homes.


Shortly after KSEDO was founded, their sponsor withdrew due to financial difficulties leaving the centre in a vulnerable position.  They now solely rely on public donations to maintain the children’s wellbeing.  


Managed primarily by one lady, Ms Chhim Sophorn the centre provides shelter, care and education to the 30 plus children at KSEDO.  Aged between 4-18 years, many were previously living alone, on the streets or in jail.  It is a safe and loving environment for the kids to have a chance at life. They sleep in timber huts built by volunteers. They do not have any showers or plumbing. Hygiene is constantly a major issue.


Educational Programmes are a big part of KSEDO’s goal to offer the children a chance at a brighter future. Accordingly, volunteering is available particularly to teach the children English, some of the difficulties they face are inconsistent periods of volunteers.

SMILES OF CAMBODIA


The mission of the foundation is to establish self-efficient English and IT schools in Cambodia (Siem Riep). Also to support communities, organisations and individuals whose aim it is help integrate orphans and severely disadvantaged kids into society.

We have the following plans for KSEDO in 2016

Building a self-efficient English and IT school in a rural village near Siem Riep, which would also function as a home and be able to accommodate up to 40 children, this would also ensure the continuous operation of the establishment.


Our Beneficiaries, Ms Chhim Sophorn and her children


Within one school year the education centre would give opportunity for more than 100 children to gain knowledge, skills and experience in their spare time and also provide food and shelter to its 40 residents throughout the year.

In the complex there will be two 250 square meter stone/wood buildings, a creative workshop and a sports field built. To support and maintain this, there is a plan to create an aquaphonics irrigation system, a mushroom cultivation and fish breeding farm, these are also to help the children’s education.




Budget:

  • Buying a land in or around Siem Reap: USD 15,000
  • Build two 250 sqaure meter stone/wood buildings: USD 35,000
  • Construction of an aquaphonics irrigation system that is capable simultaneously cultivating 400 fish and 6000 plants, with delivery from Thailand: USD 15,000
  • Mushroom breeding farm: USD 8,000
  • Fish breeding farm: USD 7,000
  • Purchase of equipments and supplies: USD 5,000
Start with the projects in Siem Reap: Beginning of January 2016
Finishing the first projects: End of May 2016

Each dollar that you can give, - no matter how small the amount is - will bring us closer to our goals. 

We are happy to work together with everybody, so if you feel like join us and let's make it happen!

Thank you for your time and support!

Smiles of Cambodia


Here is the video of the kids from Siem Reap who will be the residents of our new complex with Your help from 2016. 


For every donation we receive, the kids will be sending out a "virtual smile"  to everybody! Thank you

story:
Hi! I'm studying a Bachelor of Animal and Veterinary Biosciences at La Trobe University, and this January my partner Daryl and I will be teaming up with Volunteer Eco Students Abroad and the Laos Elephant Conservation Center to take part in an community development and elephant rehabilitation project in one of the world's top 20 poorest nations. 

Volunteer Eco Students Abroad is an organization working hand in hand with indigenous village communities to create real and lasting change. The Elephant Conservation Centre is a non-profit organisation which has been working towards the protection of elephants in Laos for over 12 years, running welfare, veterinary care, breeding and mahouts training programmes. The Centre, together with VESA, is dedicated to protecting ancestral cultures, knowledge and traditions, as well as the fragile tropical ecosystem. With only two elephants born for every ten that die, the Asian elephant, a major component of Lao cultural heritage, is under serious threat of extinction.

During our time in Laos we will be under the guidance of local communities: planting banana and sugar cane crops; maintaining the veterinary clinic and elephant nursery; building classrooms, bathroom blocks and water catchments; and working within local schools to provide an introduction to English and assist kids in breaking the poverty cycle. As people from Australia, we will be adhering to cultural practices and traditions, and be working closely with members of the community to ensure that our actions represent what is best for the region.

I am seeking donations to help facilitate the implementation of this project, which will work to educate the community on matters of conservation, sustainability, health/hygiene and English proficiency. Through our own efforts, we have raised $2000 of our $8000 goal. Any funds raised will contribute directly to the hiring of local tradespeople to supervise and assist in construction, the costs of building materials, and donations to local organisations. Please note that whilst VESA is a volunteer organisation, it is not a registered charity so donations will not be tax deductible.

To learn more about the VESA program please visit www.vesabroad.com or call 02 8005 6755. For more information about how your contribution will help save the Asian elephant and the Lao peoples, you can contact me at keturnbull@students.latrobe.edu.au.

Thank you so much.

Katie Turnbull

Through our own efforts, we have raised $2000 of our $8000 goal. Any funds raised will contribute directly to the hiring of local tradespeople to supervise and assist in construction, the costs of building materials, and donations to local organisations. Please note that whilst VESA is a volunteer organisation, it is not a registered charity so donations will not be tax deductible.To learn more about the VESA program please visit www.vesabroad.com or call 02 8005 6755. For more information about how your contribution will help save the Asian elephant and the Lao peoples, you can contact me at keturnbull@students.latrobe.edu.au.Thank you so much.Katie Turnbull

story:
Bringing mining-affected indigenous peoples together in international solidarity; fostering global activism...

Problem 

Around the world, multinational mining companies threaten indigenous lands, communities, and cultures.  The insatiable hunger for gold, silver and other minerals--and the vast profits that they bring--has cut majestic mountains down to nubs, turned pristine lakes into lesions, poisoned pure waters, and caused grave health harms from toxic chemicals used in processing ore.

But more and more, communities are standing up and saying "No!" to the ongoing plunder of their territories by mining companies.  Community defenders and anti-mining activists are not only organizing within their communities, they are forming regional alliances with other mining affected and at-risk communities. Increasingly, they understand that the unimaginable damage wrought by mines, is not a local problem--it is systemic and world-wide.  To effectively confront mining companies and hold them accountable, the struggle must be taken to the international level.  And the strength that comes from unity is critical in confronting the global problem of predatory mining for profit, at the grave expense of people and the natural world.

We ask for clean air, fertile land. No to the mine.

Anti-mining protest in San José del Progreso, Oaxaca, México

Response

So we--a coalition of human and environmental rights organizations from México, Thailand, Canada and the U.S.--have created a space for activists and community defenders from mining impacted communities around the world to come together, share stories of their struggles, weave new relationships and networks of solidarity and explore ways of working together to protect Mother Earth, their communities, and cultures.  Delegates from Thailand, U.S. Native Americans, and Canadian First Nations indigenous peoples will come together in November to meet with three mining affected Zapotec communities in Oaxaca, México.

This unique delegation, forum and festival will:

  • put individual community struggles in the international spotlight, while highlighting the commonality of each peoples' experience with destructive mining projects.  
  • foster effective networks of solidarity between mining affected communities around the world.
  • offer community defenders and activists opportunities to develop strategies for working collectively to hold mining companies and governments accountable.
  • increase public awareness of the devastating environmental, cultural, community and health harms that inevitably come with extractive mining projects.

Here is What we Need

We are raising $5,000 to cover remaining costs for the facilitation of the delegation (Oct 30 - Nov 11), and the forum and festival (Nov 12).  We have already raised funds via personal donations, grants, and coordinated a separate Indiegogo Campaign to raise funds to cover the airfare and participation costs for our Thai delegates, but we are still in need of additional funding to ensure this campaign is successful.

Specifically, the $5,000 will go to cover the following:

1.)  The costs of professional interpretation (Spanish to English to Thai) and ensuring we have enough interpreters throughout the delegation.

2.) Rental costs for Interpretation equipment to be used during the "Yes! To Life, No! to Mining" International forum and festival on November 12th.

3.) The cost of supplies and materials for a solidarity-mural the delegates will paint together at the conclusion of the trip.

4.) Professional video documentation of the entire delegation and festival and the production of several films showcasing different aspects of the trip.

5.) Expenses related to the participation of additional First Nations delegates from Canada and Native American delegates from the US.

Every dollar we raise above and beyond our $5,000 goal will be put to use enhancing the tour and festival, and will allow us to invite more participants to the forum on Nov 12th.

 
Open-pit gold mine in Loei, Thailand.

              

              

              

                             

              

"If you love life; fight agains the mine."  San José del Progreso, Oaxaca, México

Additional Outcomes:

  • A documentary film is another essential part of this project. Distribution of the film through social media and screenings in communities throughout the U.S., Thailand, the U.S., Canada and Mexico will maximize the visibility of the campaign, ensure an increased awareness of mining-related injustices, and foster support for resistance efforts.  Versions subtitled in Spanish, English, Thai, French and Zapoteco will be available, greatly broadening the reach of this project.
  • Outreach has brought us closer to being able to tell the story of mining affected communities in Thailand, Native American U.S., First Nations Canada and Mexico. From videos to profiles to graphics, this project is bringing together old and new resources. The world can no longer claim ignorance.
  • Networking with mining and human rights organizations worldwide. The list of contacts in different countries continues to grow. Mining impacted communities clearly are not alone. These organizations are becoming allies in achieving our common goal

Media Coverage

  • Delegates will hold press conferences with community radio in each of the three Oaxacan communities we will be visiting.
  • The delegation will hold a press conference the final day of the delegation in Oaxaca, México, with state and federal media present.
  • Each delegate will issue a press release and radio spot about the delegation in their home countries.
  • A documentary film on the "Yes! to Life and Mother Earth, No! to Mining delegation (mentioned above) will be produced in five languages and distributed internationally.
  • Journalist Jonathan Treat, who has written for Americas Program (www.cipamericas.org), Huffington Post (www.huffingtonpost.org), NACLA Report on the Americas (www.nacla.org), Upside Down World (www.upsidedownworld.org), etc. will publish an article and photo essay on the delegation

Who We Are


University ServicesServicios Universitarios Y Redes de Conocimientos en Oaxaca A.C. (SURCO) is a non-profit, grassroots organization that combines consulting, academic programs, and local activism in Oaxaca, Mexico. SURCO believes that knowledge is not only meant to interpret the world, but to change it. Integrating formal education and activism allows the organization to provide dynamic and diverse opportunities for program participants, while facilitating connections to the international context and to collaboration with local projects. As an active partner in a wide range of local networks that tackle social and environmental justice issues, SURCO focuses on food and water sovereignty, urban conviviality, defense of indigenous territories, and community-based radio and video.

ENGAGE is a 501(c)3 non-profit founded in 2001 by returned study abroad students who studied development and globalization in NortheastThailand.  The ENGAGE network has grown into a network of individuals and organizations linked through their involvement in local community-based social justice organizing, experiential learning, and popular education.  Via experiential learning and popular education methods, ENGAGE builds solidarity around issues of economic, social, environmental and cultural rights.

Dao Din is a group of Thai university students who have dedicated themselves to fighting human rights violations in Northeast Thailand. They work alongside communities to build campaigns supporting local autonomy over natural resources. The group is composed mostly of law students who provide legal support in addition to organizing demonstrations, educational camps, and trainings to build strategies and techniques for resisting injustice.

The Human Rights Law Center for Society is a Thai legal organization that was established in order to support villagers in cases of human rights violations. The center provides legal advice, legal education and human rights trainings, and support in strategy-development within communities.

Dao Din and the Human Rights Law Center for Society are connected by their focus and partner communities. Between Dao Din and the Human Rights Law Center for Society, Thai university students and alumni maintain strong relationships with communities resisting gold mining, natural gas drilling, river dredging, industrial projects, and top-down land reform and water management projects.

People Who Love Their Hometown (PWLTH) is a community organization comprised of concerned villagers from Na Nong Bong Village and surrounding communities in Loei Province. The group became a formal organization fighting to close Tungkum Ltd.'s mining operation in Loei since 2008 due to the mine's alleged environmental and health effects. 

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to contributing financially, here are a few other ways you can support:

  • Share our Indiegogo campaign on social media: Facebook, Twitter, Instagram
  • If you are journalist or work in media and would like to interview or write a story about this campaign or any of its participants please contact us.
  • Follow the money!  Most people are unaware of the ways in which they may, unwittingly, be complicit in supporting destructive mining projects.  Investigate where your taxes, investments, etc. are going.  The Canadian Pension Plan, for example, is heavily invested in mining projects around the world with mining companies that have well documented reputations for flagrant. environmental and human rights abuses.  For example:  
    • http://www.vice.com/en_ca/read/canadian-pensions-are-being-invested-in-a-mining-company-with-a-questionable-human-rights-record
  • Talk to friends and family about our project and spread the word about our Indiegogo campaign.
  • Talk to local businesses and corporations who might be interested in pursuing a corporate sponsorship.
  • Host an event. For example, a dinner/potluck, documentary showing, game night, art show, or party. Make this campaign your theme, and ask for donations.
  • Be mindful about your consumption of mined minerals. Consider purchasing alternatives to gold. 
  • Stay tuned to our campaign - the movement for justice builds and there will be more opportunities for you to join our campaign and let your voice be heard.

story:
From the series "Satellite Cities"

Since its independence in 1956 Morocco has been involved in developing a democratic society and open market economy based on the rule of law.  Starting from the rise to the throne of Mohammed VI in 1999, Morocco has grown steadily, increasing its economic stability, reducing unemployment and developing more and more business.
Economic growth, which has led to an increase in jobs, has allowed partly to slow down emigration and improve exports. The result is of a solid position in the African context and a more and more destination country for foreign investors."

                 

                                                    From the series "Satellite Cities"


                 

                                                      From the series "Satellite Cities"


The economic changes that took over in Morocco during the last 15 years have helped to create a reverse process of migration.

Many friends of mine have decided to leave Italy and return to Morocco driven by the desire to build a future in a country that is very promising thanks to social  and economic reforms, investments made during the last decade and more and more foreign investors coming for business.

Through repeated trips I have seen with my eyes this changing-fast process.

In June 2014 I started to think about a long-term photographic project that was intended to show the country's economic and social development.

I started to photograph the first chapter in August 2014: a major investment ( $60 Billion) who's purpose is to deal with the population growth through the construction of satellite towns located near the almost saturated suburbs of larger cities.  Currently these new cities are predominantly inhabited by that part of the population that once lived on those lands; the idea is to convince the newly born middle class to buy houses and open new business in order to avoid the construction of dormitory-towns.                                                                                                    


          

                                                From the series "Satellite Cities"


         

                                                 From the series "Satellite Cities" 


         

                                                    From the series "Satellite Cities"


I have later decided  to launch this campaign in order to be able to collect the money needed to continue this story.

With your help I will support myself in Morocco until mid/end of March 2016 and devote the next chapters of "A NOUVELLE IDENTITè" to other economic investments promoted by the government.

I will spend 10 days in Tangier and with the help of a fixer I will photograph the newly born port "TANGER MED" which is having  an important economic and social effect within it's region, Tangier-Tetuan is actually  the closest  region to Europe for commerce.  The complex is getting ready to become one of the most important in the world thanks to it's 2.5 million TEU ( Twenty-foot equivalent unit) traffic in 2013, an extension project called Tanger Med II that aims to reach 8.2 million containers and a free trade area named Tanger Free Zone that helps more than 500 international companies to relocate their production  in a high potential development area.                                       

I will then move in the souther regions of Morocco and  photograph the $ 13 billion investment in renewable energy. The construction of wind and solar farms is to ensure that the country reaches the target to source 42% of energy by 2020. In fact, until 2011 Morocco was importing 95% of electricity with serious impact on the state budget.  Once achieved, the government  plan will be to start exporting the energy.  My photography will mainly focus on the positive effects that this investment is having on the population of rural areas of the southern regions.

Many other investments are on the way: the industrial development of the oriental regions and the investment whose purpose is to strengthen the Sahara region. 


            

     ( 100% cotton fine art print from the series " Satellite Cities" )                 .                                                      18x24cm                                                                                             

             

                       ( 100% cotton fine art print from the series " Satellite Cities" )                          .                                                                         18x24cm


A LITTLE BIT ABOUT ME: 

I was born in 1990 in Lucca, Italy. After my studies in Graphic and Advertising, I firstly worked as a staff photographer for a local newspaper and after did a photojournalism course at Istituto Marangoni in Florence held by Terraproject Collective (Simone Donati and Michele Borzoni).

I’m presently living in Berlin and dedicating my time to Photography.

My long term  project "UNA NOUVELLE IDENTITè "Satellite cities" was recently awarded as finalist of the prestigious "Portfolio Italia 2015" event.

                   

           (Myself working in Tamansourt, Marrakech, sept 2014)

                                                             

                                                                     €1800 GOAL


From the  € 1800 goal I'm going to use  €600 for rewards and fees. With the  rest I will cover the whole trip:  return flight from Berlin (or Pisa) to Fez  ( approximately Feb - mid March), Hotel when needed, Fixer, Car,food to survive and the time needed for the editing of the work done.


                                                                    REWARDS

Last but not least let me explain the rewards you will receive for you support to my project. 


€10 

Your name will appear in "UNA NOUVELLE IDENTITè" in a list of the backers who made the project possible.
+
 two 12x9cm fine art postcard

€25

Your name will appear in "UNA NOUVELLE IDENTITè" in a list of the backers who made the project possible.
+
four 12x9 cm fine art postcards

or 

one 24x18 cm signed fine art print (100% cotton)



€50
Your name will appear in "UNA NOUVELLE IDENTITè" in a list of the backers who made the project possible.                                                                       
+

 one 30x24cm  signed fine art print  ( 100% cotton )

+

4 fine art 12x9 postcards


€80

Your name will appear in "UNA NOUVELLE IDENTITè" in a list of the backers who made the project possible.                                                                       

+

 three 18x24cm  signed  fine art prints  ( 100% cotton ) in an handmade clamshell box

                                              

€150

Your name will appear in "UNA NOUVELLE IDENTITè" in a list of the backers who made the project possible.                                                                     
+
 four 30x24cm  signed print  ( 100% cotton fine art certified)  in an handmade clamshell box                                                            

€200
Your name will appear in "UNA NOUVELLE IDENTITè" in a list of the backers who made the project possible.                                                                         
+
 six 30x24cm signed prints  ( 100% cotton fine art certified)  in an handmade clamshell box   

or if you prefer I will prepare two (same size) pictures framed in a natural light wooden frame.                                                                             


IN CASE YOU WOULD LIKE TO SEE A WIDER SELECTION OF PICTURES YOU JUST HAVE TO ASK AND I WILL HAVE A PDF SENT TO YOUR EMAIL.
SO ITS VERY IMPORTANT TO HAVE YOUR EMAIL AND ADDRESS GIVEN TO ME ONCE BACKED THE PROJECT.
I WILL BE POSTING YOUR PRINTS BY THE 15th OF FEBRUARY.

                          

                                                                        

                                                        

                                           

                                 

         

                                               From the series "Satellite Cities"


         

                                                 From the series "Satellite Cities"


         

                                                  From the series "Satellite Cities"   


                                                       RISKS & CHALLENGES

In terms or risks related to rewards hopefully there won't be any. I will fly back  to Italy 2 weeks before Morocco and I will prepare the prints and the clamshell boxes.                    

Regarding the actual realisation of the project:                                                                       I'm presently working hard  to get all the permits required to photograph the free trade zone in Tangier  and the various Wind and Solar farms.                                                    I can't  predict with certainty what happens once I will be in Morocco but for sure I'm very positive about the fact that my determination along with your support will play an important role in this adventure.                                                                                      It's also important for me to point out that this couldn't come true without the endless help and hospitality of my Moroccan friends.

         

          

         

               Maroccan soldier  jailed for 25 years by the Polisario Front in Sahara 

          

                                                 From the series "Satellite Cities"

Through repeated trips I have seen with my eyes this changing-fast process.
In June 2014 I started to think about a long-term photographic project that was intended to show the country's economic and social development.
I started to photograph the first chapter in August 2014: a major investment ( $60 Billion) who's purpose is to deal with the population growth through the construction of satellite towns located near the almost saturated suburbs of larger cities.  Currently these new cities are predominantly inhabited by that part of the population that once lived on those lands; the idea is to convince the newly born middle class to buy houses and open new business in order to avoid the construction of dormitory-towns.                                                                                                    


                                                          From the series "Satellite Cities"                                                          From the series "Satellite Cities"                                                              From the series "Satellite Cities"I have later decided  to launch this campaign in order to be able to collect the money needed to continue this story.
With your help I will support myself in Morocco until mid/end of March 2016 and devote the next chapters of "A NOUVELLE IDENTITè" to other economic investments promoted by the government.
I will spend 10 days in Tangier and with the help of a fixer I will photograph the newly born port "TANGER MED" which is having  an important economic and social effect within it's region, Tangier-Tetuan is actually  the closest  region to Europe for commerce.  The complex is getting ready to become one of the most important in the world thanks to it's 2.5 million TEU ( Twenty-foot equivalent unit) traffic in 2013, an extension project called Tanger Med II that aims to reach 8.2 million containers and a free trade area named Tanger Free Zone that helps more than 500 international companies to relocate their production  in a high potential development area.                                       
I will then move in the souther regions of Morocco and  photograph the $ 13 billion investment in renewable energy. The construction of wind and solar farms is to ensure that the country reaches the target to source 42% of energy by 2020. In fact, until 2011 Morocco was importing 95% of electricity with serious impact on the state budget.  Once achieved, the government  plan will be to start exporting the energy.  My photography will mainly focus on the positive effects that this investment is having on the population of rural areas of the southern regions.Many other investments are on the way: the industrial development of the oriental regions and the investment whose purpose is to strengthen the Sahara region. 
            
     ( 100% cotton fine art print from the series " Satellite Cities" )                 .                                                      18x24cm                                                                                             
             
                       ( 100% cotton fine art print from the series " Satellite Cities" )                          .                                                                         18x24cm

A LITTLE BIT ABOUT ME: 
I was born in 1990 in Lucca, Italy. After my studies in Graphic and Advertising, I firstly worked as a staff photographer for a local newspaper and after did a photojournalism course at Istituto Marangoni in Florence held by Terraproject Collective (Simone Donati and Michele Borzoni).
I’m presently living in Berlin and dedicating my time to Photography.
My long term  project "UNA NOUVELLE IDENTITè "Satellite cities" was recently awarded as finalist of the prestigious "Portfolio Italia 2015" event.
                   
           (Myself working in Tamansourt, Marrakech, sept 2014)
                                                             
                                                                     €1800 GOAL

From the  € 1800 goal I'm going to use  €600 for rewards and fees. With the  rest I will cover the whole trip:  return flight from Berlin (or Pisa) to Fez  ( approximately Feb - mid March), Hotel when needed, Fixer, Car,food to survive and the time needed for the editing of the work done.

Last but not least let me explain the rewards you will receive for you support to my project.

               Maroccan soldier  jailed for 25 years by the Polisario Front in Sahara

story: *

Short Summary

We’re a team behind fifteen articles on GitLabFan.com. If we were foxes we'd look something like this :)

We’re passionate about GitLab. It is a powerful instrument, and GitLab CI is one of its most impressive parts.

We see that many developers underestimate the effects of automation. They keep wasting their time and energy on the same routine tasks every day. Instead, they could invest some efforts in automation and delegate the most of the routine to GitLab CI!

We creating this course because we believe that
Robots Should Be Busy! Not humans (or foxes)!

For most beginners, it is hard to learn by reading the documentation. The documentation is comprehensive, but it is not what they need.

For a beginner, it is easier to grasp new concepts when they learn them step by step in the form of a story. When there is a story, you do not only understand “Hows,” you also learn “Why-s,” which is even more important!

This course will be a set of short stories about a team developing a product, meeting real-world and not so real-world challenges and overcoming them with the help of GitLab CI.

The course will have three levels(see full plan draft at the bottom of the page): 

  1. GitLab CI basics
  2. Becoming a Pro
  3. Advanced Level

The more support we get, the more advanced topics we’ll add to the course!!

By now, we’re at the end of the planning stage, and ready to start creating!

What We Need & What You Get

We’re going to create this course no matter what! However, more advanced topics require additional research, so your support is very important for us!

We're about to make around 20 illustrated lessons, record at least 10 screencasts, and prepare a homework for every important concept.

We also want to give our supporters something special, so we’re preparing not only digital perks, but also physical. 

Check them out. You'll find there:

  • GitLab Fan sticker packs 
  • GitLab Fan t-shirts with the course logo
  • Printed cards with picked GitLab principles

(pictures will be posted here soon :)

The Impact

We believe it is important to teach beginner developers about the concept of Continuous Integration. It can save so much time and make them happier by allowing them to work more on creative tasks instead of routine.

We also believe that GitLab CI is a perfect fit for that goal. 

  • It has clean semantics and concise syntax
  • It is technology-agnostic so that you can use it with any programming language of choice
  • It is integrated into GitLab, so it requires less integration and configuration than other CI tools

If we reach the goal of $8000, we will also create a separate course for beginners about the flow of work in GitLab and make it available for free for anyone!

We’ve been running GitLabFan.com for more than six months. Now we want to move our project to the next level and create something more impactful! Please join  can help us with that!

Risks & Challenges

Finding a good way to teach is always a challenge. Finding a good metaphor for a concept, finding a good example to demonstrate the usefulness of an approach, drawing an illustration - it all requires time and concentration. 

Sometimes you have to re-work your materials for two-three times until you finally become satisfied with it.

But we love this kind of challenges, and the final result is the best motivation!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you’re already an expert in GitLab CI, and don't need an access to the class, you can still help us:

  • Choose one of the perks without class admission!
  • Buy class admission for a friend as a present!
  • Spread the word about this course across your friends!

 

Let's keep robots busy together!!

 

The course structure

Getting your first pipeline running

  • gitlab-ci.yml
  • The most minimal CI configuration 
  • Success & failure
  • Broken config —> CI linter
  • UI & Pipeline results

Parallel & sequential jobs execution, build results

  • Adding one more step (parallel execution)
  • Sequential jobs execution
  • Passing files between stages
  • Making build results downloadable

Simplest possible deployment

  • Secret variables
  • Environment variables

Providing environments for our scripts

  • Installing missing software packages
  • Using custom docker images
  • Different images for different stages

Collaboration

  • "Only" & "except" rules
  • Manual steps

Building complex pipelines

  • Build - test - deploy cycle
  • Deploying to different places

GitLab CI terminology & mechanics

  • Jobs, runners, stages, pipelines
  • How pipeline works
  • Every job is executed in isolated environment
  • Why you need to pass artifacts between stages

Optimizing pipeline execution time

  • Caching installed packages
  • Building custom docker images
  • Hosting custom docker images in GitLab Registry

Environments

  • Why deployment from a local machine is a bad idea
  • CI helps to keep track of all your deployments
  • Rollback

Deployment tips & tricks

  • Deploying to VPS(SSH keys workaround)
  • GitLab Pages
  • dpl gem

Review apps

  • Building review apps manually
  • Destroying review app
  • Automatical review apps

Integrations

  • Slack
  • Mattermost
  • Notifications
  • Triggering deployment from Slack

Triggering builds

  • Schedule
  • Sync with GitHub/Bitbucket
  • API

Bells & whistles

  • Test coverage badge
  • CI status badge
  • Group-level variables

Advanced level

  1. Using built-in variables
  2. Building Docker images inside GitLab CI
  3. Yaml tricks
  4. GitLab Runners
  5. Building build matrix
  6. How GitLab uses GitLab CI

If we've missed something or you have some interesting use case to cover, don't hesitate to reach us with this typeform.

story:
Who is Poetry & Rhyme?

                  

Who: Poetry & Rhyme is an outreach project of Silent Fire Productions created in 2007.

What: A music and animation video project that works with immigrant students to help them learn English, give them an opportunity to express themselves, and expose them to the field of media.

When: Every spring and fall.

Where: In Loudoun County, Virginia public schools in need.

How: With the help of co-operating reading specialists and English language teachers, students take six weeks to create the material for video classes based on a theme. They incorporate their academic requirements into what they create. Then Silent Fire Productions comes down from NYC and films and produces the video. Because this video is created by students for students, it is shared both in the classroom and online through social media.

Why: By participating in the music video, students have a chance to channel their fears, memories and hopes into words. By feeling that their experiences are important and that they are not alone in feeling them, they are less likely to join gangs and more likely to continue on with their education and graduate. They improve their English reading, writing and speaking skills. Working together as a team and being exposed to media making tools opens up possibilities for both their academic and career futures.

By sharing the finished video with other students it allows for students in similar situations to feel connected to others and feel as if they are not alone. Such a simple thing like not feeling alone can make a significant difference in a child's life.

What We Need & What You Get:

Time. All we ask for is time with our kids. #gotaminute?
 $1 = 1 minute with our students. It's simple, for every dollar that you donate, it gives us one minute that we are able to work with our students. And every one who donates is remembered in some way for helping out in our campaign. From being memorialized on our Wall of Heros on the website for everyone to see, to being listed as a Producer in this Fall's video credits, to being invited to our wrap party to meet our students. From out of town? Not a problem! We can skype you in.

Who are We?

We are a handful of crazy passionate, social justice, human rights minded educators, teachers, designers and producers. We are ELL (English Lanuage Learner) teachers, Reading specialists, Graphic, Video and Sound Designers and Creative Directors. Between us we have a PhD, 6 Masters degrees, 8 Bachelor degrees, a handful or teaching and other certificates and a whole lot of life experience. Many of us have been teaching and producing for over ten years. We've even got two mother-daughter teams working with us. For more info on us, check out the team.

How else can you help us?

1. Share. Share. Share. Our blog, or any of our social media. The campaign link too.

2. We are always looking for volunteers! Want more info? Contact us here.

3. Send us updates on news that could be related/affected by our project. Share it on our social media or send it to us directly. We like to stay connected.

story:
Thanks for visiting! I'm independent candidate for Elizabeth, recording artist and activist Terneille Burrows aka "TaDa". Through supporting this process, you help me to do outreach in our constituency as follows:

  • Public education on important national issues - through social media
  • Community engagement through meet n' greets and constituency-based forums
  • Branding 'Independent Elizabeth' through: website, merchandising etc.

    Our Elizabeth will seek to keep constituents abreast of key current affairs and national issues; engage in discussions, debates and idea-building plus encourage on-going community service.

Annual Budget Outline:

Operations
  • Office rental - $13,200 ($1,100/month)
  • Utilities (electricity, water, internet, telepone) - $6,000 ($500/month)
  • Computer - $2,000
  • Courier - $1,000
  • All-in-One Printer/Copier/Scanner - $600
  • Office supplies - $500
Section total = $23,300
Marketing
  • Brand development (website, logo, merchandise etc.) - $3,000
  • Traditional marketing (radio, newspaper ads) - $3,000
  • Social media marketing - $2,500
  • Flyers - $2,500
Section total = $11,000
Outreach & Community Meetings
  • Professional lecture series (bi-weekly) - $13,000
  • Public Service Announcement videos - $3,000
Section total = $16,000
Grand Total = $50,300
