story:
Dear Sir or Madam,

I would like to share my most recent life-changing story with you. I have been involved with an car accident in October of last year. As a result, I have broken 4 bones and lost approximately 50% of blood, and thanks to the help of doctors and hospital staff, I was able to survive what most were not.

As the old saying "nothing comes with a price," I am in debt to all the various medical expenses incurred upon me. I am currently a student in university in which I have been working diligently in the past years to help paying off my tuition, and I live with my dad who was divorced and recently lost his job, and my 80-year-old grandma who requires constant attention and care. As time went by I started to slowly recover, and with the starting of a new year and beginning of a new semester, I have to endure the pain and the physical difficulty by commuting between classes with crutches and wheelchairs. Thanks to my most respectful dad, who has been helping me commuting to school and dedicating the rest of his time to a little bit of money he makes here and there, with minimum hours of sleep at night to help support the family.

As you can see, my family has now fallen into a catastrophic situation. With all these responsibilities that I am currently obliged to fulfill, I am unable to pay off the expensive medical bill incurred upon my treatment. My goal is to raise $100,000, and I I sincerely ask for financial assistance from you and I will deeply appreciate with any of the help I can get! I can be best reached at shensen.gao@yahoo.com

Thank you very much!
story_txt:
Dear Sir or Madam,I would like to share my most recent life-changing story with you. I have been involved with an car accident in October of last year. As a result, I have broken 4 bones and lost approximately 50% of blood, and thanks to the help of doctors and hospital staff, I was able to survive what most were not.As the old saying "nothing comes with a price," I am in debt to all the various medical expenses incurred upon me. I am currently a student in university in which I have been working diligently in the past years to help paying off my tuition, and I live with my dad who was divorced and recently lost his job, and my 80-year-old grandma who requires constant attention and care. As time went by I started to slowly recover, and with the starting of a new year and beginning of a new semester, I have to endure the pain and the physical difficulty by commuting between classes with crutches and wheelchairs. story:
The Research

Minecraft is one of the most popular video games on the market today. It is remarkably simple yet offers a seemingly endless number of engineering possibilities for its players. 

We are researching what educational value the game holds for the children who play it. These include:

  • Spatial Reasoning
  • Engineering Resource Management
  • Constraint-based Engineering and Design
  • Engineering Interest Among Students
There is evidence that playing with Legos has a positive effect on students engineering abilities. This research would attempt to gauge the levels to which playing Minecraft has on these skills and determine its appropriate use in classroom environments. 

What We Need 

We have built a Minecraft server from existing equipment and have obtained permission to use (free of charge) a test to measure spatial reasoning. What we need is the ability to reward students who are willing to participate in the study with a gift card. We currently have the funding to supply lunch (pizza) to all participants and a couple of gift cards that can be raffled off, but we would like to reward all participants with a gift card. We need your help to do that!

Each student will take two tests, a survey, and participate in a design challenge. It would be great to be able to thank each one of them and the students volunteering with the research administration with a gift card. 

This is not a product and we cannot offer anything in the way of perks other than our deep gratitude for your support which we will be happy to write a letter of thanks for everyone who supports this research. 

The Impact

This research will attempt to identify new methods of teaching basic engineering and spatial skills. It will supply the students participating with a fun and rewarding experience and give the students assisting with the research a unique opportunity to work on real research. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please get the message out to everyone you know. Share our campaign on social media and with your friends and family. Any support helps!


All contributions are tax deductible through The PUSH Initiative, a 501(c)(3) non-profit.

story:
The Insight Project (TIP) has created a new and efficient technology that generates electricity better than solar and wind at a quarter of the cost, with better reliability and longer life. The system is based on a new turbine design that converts heat, from any source, to electricity.

We are ready to go into production of the system. The turbine technology is proven, prototyped, tested and ready to be manufactured for affordable residential energy production with the lowest carbon footprint possible for energy generation. 

The home energy unit is just the first application of the turbine. The TIP team is creating devices that make a positive environmental and economic change for the world. We are already working on designs for everything from a new automotive engine to energy-producing floor tiles and so much more.

Would you like to be a part of that? Then support TIP and make alternative energy a real option.

story:
Thank you for clicking on our fundraising page! If that video didn't draw you in, then hopefully this letter will show you what we stand for here at Exponential Education.

Exponential Education started with a mission to help provide education and resources to students in need. It wasn't enough to give traditional scholarships or to simply fund volunteer tutoring programs - we wanted to impact students at all levels and engage them within their own community. The result was our flagship Expo Peer-to-Peer (P2P) programs, which targets high school students at financial risk of dropping out, and provided them with scholarships and stipends to stay in school, graduate, and eventually continue their academic careers. However, these scholarships were in no way a hand-out. In return for scholarships, our high school students worked hard to provide math and English tutoring to struggling junior high school students. Those younger students not only gained crucial math and English skills, but also confidence, role models, and mentors. 

What started as a backyard pilot program has transformed into a full-fledged operation. Currently, Exponential Education has a volunteer staff of 12 on the ground, and affects the lives of over 800 children a year. 

Along with our flagship tutoring program Expo P2P, we have grown our organization to include new initiatives, such as our girls leadership programs (Girls LEAP) and vocational training programs (Expo BUILD), and we make sure to monitor and evaluate our efforts through rigorous methods which prove the efficacy of our programs. Now that we have evidence, a staff, and a portfolio of programs, we are ready and excited to scale. 

This year we are aiming to raise $40,000 USD through combined fundraising platforms in order to expand our programs. These funds will go directly to supporting our programs on the ground, and as we have an all-volunteer staff, after transaction fees 97% of donations will go solely to program costs. 

For those of you who have supported us over the years, you have watched our students grow, read their letters, and seen their interviews and success stories. This money empowers them not only to finish school but now also to gain crucial leadership skills and vocational skills so that they are ready for their future after graduation.

If you can, please support our cause and donate today. We understand that not everyone can donate, and are therefore always looking for contributions in other ways, including technical training, volunteering, or additions to the board. Also, sharing with friends or family helps us tremendously to spread awareness about our programs and cause.

Please donate and let us know if you would like a tax deductible receipt in return.

Thank you for being a crucial part of our organization’s growth. It's donors like you that help keep our organization growing and our students learning.

story:
In May 2015 the 7th Grade Class of the Bolinas-Stinson Beach School is going on a Science Field Trip to the UTAH desert to study Earth’s Geological History!  

       

This year's 7th grade class has the opportunity to continue the tradition of the well-known and loved Utah trip with their teacher Don Jolley. This tradition is a unique highlight of our community's school experience and one which students are offered a profound academic expedition and experience. 


What We Are Asking

Each family has contributed funds for their child and for chaperons and the trip has received support from the Bolinas Stinson Beach School foundation, however $5,000. still needs to be raised before the class can embark on this adventure. Please consider making a tax-deductible contribution to help keep this tradition alive! 

Now for more details...

             

The Field Trip

For the last 18 years, students from the Bolinas-Stinson Beach School’s 7th grade class have journeyed to Utah's San Rafael Swell for the purpose of studying Earth’s dynamic history. This interdisciplinary program has become a distinguishing feature of the school's science curriculum and gives students a unique learning experience, far removed from the confines of a normal classroom. Led by their teacher Don Jolley, students explore geology in Utah and parts of Nevada and Wyoming. 

Roughly following the route navigated by Clarence King during his 1876 "Survey of the Fortieth Parallel," students will study the diverse layers of earth deposited over millions of years and the various forms of life dating back to the time when dinosaurs inhabited the landscape.

As they travel the 1800 mile trip, students examine the extensive geologic record,  explore sediments from the Mesozoic Era, prospect for fossil deposits, study ancient pictographs on sandstone walls, and map a dinosaur track-way near Arches national Park. Although most of their stay will be within the San Rafael Swell near Moab Utah, the route begins at the University of Nevada in Reno and finishes north at Wyoming's Fossil Butte where students will quarry for fish fossils from the world renowned Green River Formation.

                                  

In the course of 12 days on the road, 

Students unravel 6 million years of Earth’s History. 

                                   

Driven by the theme "change over time," the curriculum incorporates studies in science, art, earth and cultural histories, language arts, and mathematics. Students will learn to read topographic and geologic maps at various scales, employ plane-table survey skills in the mapping of dinosaur footprints, identify and catalogue fossils, examine pictograph materials, all the while drawing and writing daily in journals and log books through out this expedition. Through exposure and experience they learn to read the landscape and reconstruct a history recorded in fragments strewn over hundreds of miles of Western Interior. 

                                 

Upon their return to California, students will use their field data to construct maps of fossil track-ways, employ algebraic formulas to calculate speeds of animals long since extinct, and compose a final paper of reflection in response to their individual and group experience.

How You Can Help Us

Maybe you are a family member of a 7th grade student this year, or an alumnus of the trip and know first hand about this amazing experience. You might be the parent of a student who will attend the trip in the future, or perhaps you are a community member who would like to support our students, our school and this unique extracurricular opportunity. Whatever the motivation, your deeply appreciated and tax deductible donation will go directly toward the costs associated with our May 2015 Utah Field Trip (fuel, food, H20, & camping fees). 

The total cost for our group of travelers will be $12,000.  We have already secured a donation from the Bolinas-Stinson Beach School Foundation, as well as parent contributions. However, we still need to raise a significant portion of the funds to support this amazing field trip. If we exceed our goal, the extra proceeds with go toward future Utah Trips.

   Please take a moment to make a contribution.  

             You can also help by getting the word out to others!  

Or join us for the kids pizza bake down at the community park using the cob oven and selling their hand made pizza on March 28th! More details to come.
If you would prefer to donate by check our address is: Bolinas-Stinson Beach School Foundation, PO Box 43, Bolinas CA, 94924

Your support will help the 7th grade class of 2015 embark on an incredible, once in a lifetime, curriculum enriching field trip that will be remembered forever. 

               

THANK YOU!

-- Parents & Students of the 7th Grade Class, Bolinas-Stinson Union School District

story:
Comayagua Wi-LAC (red inalambrica libre, abierta y comunitaria) (community, open and free wireless network) 

Hola me llamo Luis Garcia vivo en la ciudad de Comayagua, en Honduras y al igual que en muchos países en vías de desarrollo el acceso a tecnologías de información y comunicaciones por parte de la población es muy limitado, y en su mayoría  estos servicios están en manos de proveedores que muchas veces ponen por encima sus intereses comerciales y políticos por sobre las necesidades del usuario.

Hello!  My name is Luis, I live in Comayagua, Honduras as in many developing countries the population access to information and communication technologies is very limited, and mostly in the hands of providers who often put over their commercial and political interests over the needs of the user.

Como alternativa y para beneficio de las personas se implementará en la ciudad de Comayagua el proyecto Wi-LAC que es una red basada en tecnología inalámbrica (wireless) que permite el Libre tránsito de la información, es abierta a la incorporación de participantes sin restricción alguna y es hecha por la comunidad, gestionada por la comunidad y para la comunidad.

Alternatively, the Wi-LAC project will be implemented in Comayagua city, which is a network based on wireless technology which allows the free movement of information, is open to the incorporation of participants without any restriction and is made by the community, managed by the community and for the community.

Al principio del proyecto la red inalámbrica brindará una cobertura aproximada de 1 km en determinada área de la ciudad, las personas se conectaran a la red de manera gratuita y tendrán acceso a una enciclopedia (wikipedia) en la que podrán buscar información de cualquier tipo, además podrán compartir archivos como en cualquier red local. A medida la red vaya creciendo aumentará la cobertura de la misma (hasta cubrir toda la ciudad), sus servicios y sus aplicaciones (no hay límites).

At the beginning of the project the wireless network will offer a 1 km approximate coverage in certain area of the city, the persons will get connected to the network of a free way and will have access to an encyclopedia (wikipedia) in that they will be able to look for information of any type, also they will be able to share files as in any local network. To measurement the network is growing there will increase the coverage of the same one (to cover the entire city), its services and its applications (there are no limits).

Una red con esta características tendrá un impacto positivo en sectores como el Educativo, las comunicaciones, será una opción para compartir archivos, e incluso para el entretenimiento (juegos, música, videos, películas) y cualquier otro uso que la comunidad puede imaginarse.

A network with these features will have a positive impact on sectors as education, communications, will be an option to share files, and even entertainment (games, music, videos, films) and any other use which the community can imagine.

Que necesito, que recibes (What i need, what you get)

He decidido iniciar el proyecto con la construcción e instalación de lo siguiente: 1 Nodo Inalámbrico (costo aproximado $ 100), 1 punto de acceso de largo alcance (costo aproximado $ 200), adecuación de una computadora para usar como servidor( costo aproximado $ 200), esto da un total de $500 dólares.

I have decided to start the project with construction and installation of the following: 1 wireless node (approximate cost US$100), 1 access point long-range (approximate cost US$200), adequacy of a computer to use as a server( approximate cost US$200), this gives a total of US$500.

Si contribuyes con $ 1 te enviaré una nota de agradecimiento via correo electronico desde Comayagua Wi-LAC.

If you contribute with US$1 I will send to Thank you note route e-mail from Comayagua Wi-LAC.

Si contribuyes con $ 5 te enviaré una copia digital de manuales y guías que se utilicen o generen durante la realización del proyecto Comayagua Wi-LAC.

If you contribute with US$5 will send to you a digital copy of manuals, guides and any other material that is used or generated during the achievement of Comayagua Wi-LAC.

Si contribuyes con $ 100 tu nombre aparecerá en los créditos de cualquier documento que se genere durante este proyecto.

If you contribute with $ 100 your name will appear in the credits of any document that is generated during this project.

En caso de no lograr la meta el dinero quedará en un fondo que se usará para activar el proyecto.

In case of not achieving the goal, the money will be in a fund that will be used to activate the project.

El impacto (The impact)

Comayagua Wi-LAC es una oportunidad de beneficiar e involucrar a la población de la comunidad ( de la Ciudad de Comayagua) volviendolos actores integrales de su propio desarrollo (en este caso aprovechando las tecnologías de información y comunicaciones). Este proyecto brindará acceso a la ciudadanía a una red inalámbrica libre, abierta y gestionada por la comunidad por lo que las posibilidades son infinitas y reales.

Comayagua Wi-LAC is an opportunity to benefit and to involve the population of the community (of the City of Comayagua) turning them integral actors of its own development (in this case making use of the technologies of information and communications). This project will provide access to the citizenship to a free, open wireless network managed by the community for what the possibilities are infinite and real.

Hagamos este proyecto realidad desde la comunidad. Educación, entretenimiento  y comunicación sin límites…

Let us make this project a reality from the community. Education, entertainment and open communication

Riesgos y desafios (Risks and challenges)

Uno de los más grandes retos de este proyecto es convencer a las personas de la ciudad de su  importancia y de que este debe ser realizado por ellos y para ellos. Para solventar esto se ejecutarán las estrategias necesarias para motivar a la comunidad.

One of the biggest challenges of this project is to convince the people of the city of its importance and that this should be done by them and for them. Strategies to motivate the community will be implemented to solve this.

Otro aspecto a tomar en cuenta es la normativa y legislación nacional para lo cual desde la misma comunidad deberán realizarse los análisis y estudios necesarios para actuar dentro de la legalidad nacional.

Another aspect to consider is the law and national legislation which from the same community analyzes and studies needed to act within the national legislation should be made.

Como en cualquier red informática los riesgos de seguridad deben ser tomados en cuenta, para esto se establecerán mecanismos de protección que cumplan con las normas y estándares de calidad nacionales e internacionales de seguridad de redes inalámbricas.

As in any computer network security risks must be taken into account, for this will be established protection mechanisms that comply with the rules and standards of quality national and international security on wireless networks.

Otras formas de ayudar (Other ways to help)

Otra forma de brindar soporte a este proyecto es  compartiendolo a través de las redes sociales con todos tus amigos. No te olvides también de visitar y compartir nuestra página de facebook.

Another way to provide support to this project is sharing it east across social networks with your friends (do not forget to give a pass through our page in facebook.

La asistencia técnica, ideas y equipos tecnológicos también son bien recibidos (no te olvides que tú puedes ser parte activa de este proyecto participando en la construccion e implementacion de la red planificando y montando tu propio nodo).

Technical assistance, ideas and equipment are also welcome.

At the beginning of the project the wireless network will offer a 1 km approximate coverage in certain area of the city, the persons will get connected to the network of a free way and will have access to an encyclopedia (wikipedia) in that they will be able to look for information of any type, also they will be able to share files as in any local network. To measurement the network is growing there will increase the coverage of the same one (to cover the entire city), its services and its applications (there are no limits).

Una red con esta características tendrá un impacto positivo en sectores como el Educativo, las comunicaciones, será una opción para compartir archivos, e incluso para el entretenimiento (juegos, música, videos, películas) y cualquier otro uso que la comunidad puede imaginarse.
A network with these features will have a positive impact on sectors as education, communications, will be an option to share files, and even entertainment (games, music, videos, films) and any other use which the community can imagine.

Que necesito, que recibes (What i need, what you get)
He decidido iniciar el proyecto con la construcción e instalación de lo siguiente: 1 Nodo Inalámbrico (costo aproximado $ 100), 1 punto de acceso de largo alcance (costo aproximado $ 200), adecuación de una computadora para usar como servidor( costo aproximado $ 200), esto da un total de $500 dólares.I have decided to start the project with construction and installation of the following: 1 wireless node (approximate cost US$100), 1 access point long-range (approximate cost US$200), adequacy of a computer to use as a server( approximate cost US$200), this gives a total of US$500.Si contribuyes con $ 1 te enviaré una nota de agradecimiento via correo electronico desde Comayagua Wi-LAC.If you contribute with US$1 I will send to Thank you note route e-mail from Comayagua Wi-LAC.Si contribuyes con $ 5 te enviaré una copia digital de manuales y guías que se utilicen o generen durante la realización del proyecto Comayagua Wi-LAC.If you contribute with US$5 will send to you a digital copy of manuals, guides and any other material that is used or generated during the achievement of Comayagua Wi-LAC.Si contribuyes con $ 100 tu nombre aparecerá en los créditos de cualquier documento que se genere durante este proyecto.If you contribute with $ 100 your name will appear in the credits of any document that is generated during this project.En caso de no lograr la meta el dinero quedará en un fondo que se usará para activar el proyecto.In case of not achieving the goal, the money will be in a fund that will be used to activate the project. 
El impacto (The impact) 
Comayagua Wi-LAC es una oportunidad de beneficiar e involucrar a la población de la comunidad ( de la Ciudad de Comayagua) volviendolos actores integrales de su propio desarrollo (en este caso aprovechando las tecnologías de información y comunicaciones). Este proyecto brindará acceso a la ciudadanía a una red inalámbrica libre, abierta y gestionada por la comunidad por lo que las posibilidades son infinitas y reales.Comayagua Wi-LAC is an opportunity to benefit and to involve the population of the community (of the City of Comayagua) turning them integral actors of its own development (in this case making use of the technologies of information and communications). This project will provide access to the citizenship to a free, open wireless network managed by the community for what the possibilities are infinite and real.Hagamos este proyecto realidad desde la comunidad. Educación, entretenimiento  y comunicación sin límites…Let us make this project a reality from the community. Education, entertainment and open communication

Riesgos y desafios (Risks and challenges)

  
Uno de los más grandes retos de este proyecto es convencer a las personas de la ciudad de su  importancia y de que este debe ser realizado por ellos y para ellos. Para solventar esto se ejecutarán las estrategias necesarias para motivar a la comunidad.
One of the biggest challenges of this project is to convince the people of the city of its importance and that this should be done by them and for them. Strategies to motivate the community will be implemented to solve this.
Otro aspecto a tomar en cuenta es la normativa y legislación nacional para lo cual desde la misma comunidad deberán realizarse los análisis y estudios necesarios para actuar dentro de la legalidad nacional.
Another aspect to consider is the law and national legislation which from the same community analyzes and studies needed to act within the national legislation should be made.
Como en cualquier red informática los riesgos de seguridad deben ser tomados en cuenta, para esto se establecerán mecanismos de protección que cumplan con las normas y estándares de calidad nacionales e internacionales de seguridad de redes inalámbricas.
As in any computer network security risks must be taken into account, for this will be established protection mechanisms that comply with the rules and standards of quality national and international security on wireless networks.

Otras formas de ayudar (Other ways to help)





Otra forma de brindar soporte a este proyecto es  compartiendolo a través de las redes sociales con todos tus amigos. No te olvides también de visitar y compartir nuestra página de facebook.
Another way to provide support to this project is sharing it east across social networks with your friends (do not forget to give a pass through our page in facebook.
La asistencia técnica, ideas y equipos tecnológicos también son bien recibidos (no te olvides que tú puedes ser parte activa de este proyecto participando en la construccion e implementacion de la red planificando y montando tu propio nodo).
Technical assistance, ideas and equipment are also welcome.

story:
What We've Done

Our garden is continuing to grow, thrive, and serve our 400 K-5 students in Oakland, and as we expand, we need your support!

With the $2,033 we raised through community contributions last spring, we were able to fund:

  • A solar-powered drip irrigation system that runs throughout all 6 raised beds and 4 planter boxes (installed by Planting Justice)

  • Lumber and other materials to build a circle of benches, so our students now have somewhere to sit in the garden (generously built by friend of the garden Karl Glaub)

  • A toolshed and tools for little hands, including trowels, hand tillers, half shovels, watering cans, gardening gloves, harvesting shears, and more

  • A 6 x 8 foot walk-in greenhouse to start plants from seed year-round

  • Installation of a mini orchard of 14 fruit trees, including apple, pear, pluot, pomegranate, and fig trees (planted by Common Vision)

  • Countless seed packets, vegetable and flower starts, pots, tomato cages, trellises, and odds and ends needed to keep our space beautiful and functional

See our first successful campaign here: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/help-us-build-a-thriving-school-garden-at-lwl/x/6491738#/story

What We Need

With the additional $2000 we're asking for, we hope to fund:

  • Additional turnable compost bins, to set up 3-stage compost

  • Materials to build shelving inside our greenhouse and toolshed

  • Materials for a mosaic and a second mural (tiles, plywood, tile cutters, glue, grout, paint, brushes, etc.)

  • More fruit tree saplings, and the ability to regularly prune/maintain existing trees

  • Materials to build additional raised beds and a solar oven

  • More tools, seed packets, starts, trellises and tomato cages, replacement tubing and hardware for our drip irrigation system, tarps, soil, mulch, and more

Our Gifts to You

Aside from knowing that you're doing a great thing, we have a few student-made gifts as thank yous for your generosity:
  • Any amount: your name will be painted on our list of "community partners" when we create our next mural
  • $30 - You'll get a package of hand-written thank you letters from students.
  • $50 - Every growing season, our kids dry out plants that have gone to seed, and harvest seeds from the pods. You'll get a package of seeds harvested from our garden, in a packet decorated by students.
  • $100 - Our kids will make you a potted succulent garden just like this one (all succulents will be propagated from leaves, which is our new favorite garden project: learn more about it here). **Please only claim this perk if you live in the Bay Area, or can have someone in the Bay Area pick it up for you.

The Impact

We at Learning Without Limits elementary school are continuing to turn what was formerly a slab of asphalt into a beautiful outdoor classroom, where students will learn nutrition, environmental awareness, scientific observation and inquiry, and hands-on cultivating skills.

East Oakland – where we teach – is a food desert, with more liquor stores and fast food restaurants than grocery stores with fresh produce. Schools like mine can play a dramatic role in shifting students’ relationship with food, which is a lifestyle change that sticks with them their whole lives. Through working in educational gardens on other campuses, we have seen firsthand how kids' eating habits can be completely transformed by the powerful, yet simple, act of growing their own food. With childhood obesity, heart disease, and type II diabetes ravaging communities like East Oakland, access to healthy food becomes a social justice issue.

In the past year, we’ve made a lot of progress toward our vision of growing healthy bodies and minds through the garden, but we’re nowhere near done. With even a $5 contribution, you join our movement for a healthier Oakland, one child at a time.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren’t able to make a financial contribution right now but still want to help, here are other things we need besides cash:

  • Used tools: anything and everything that a young child would be able to use

  • Donations of plant material, particularly trees, native plants. and edible perennials

  • People power to help with building projects

  • Advice from anyone who’s designed and launched a school garden from scratch before – we need your expertise!

Please email us (Sonya Mehta and Monica Woodworth) directly, if you have any resources or information that can help us in getting this vision off the ground: ms.sonya.mehta@gmail.com and woodworthmo@gmail.com

Our deepest thanks, in advance, for opening your hearts and wallets for our students – we can’t do this without you!

story:
For people missing an upper-limb, lack of a prosthetic is a major disability that affects their quality of life. Everyday tasks such as tying shoelaces, eating with a knife and fork, or using a zipper, are difficult for amputees. Missing limbs can lead to social exclusion, and difficulty in gaining meaningful employment. In developing countries, the availability of prosthetic devices is extremely limited, yet the demand there is the greatest. The Victoria Hand Project (VHP) is focused on getting prosthetic hands to those amputees who need them. We’ve designed a low-cost, high-function, customized, 3D printed upper-limb prosthesis system. It’s specifically designed for production in developing countries where it’s needed. With our prosthetic hand, amputees can regain function, improve their quality of life, and may have better access to employment opportunities.

The Victoria Hand is a complete body-powered prosthesis consisting of a hand, a wrist, a limb-socket, and a harness. It has high functionality, natural-appearance, and is custom-made to fit each amputee.

The hand is capable of adaptive grasp, which allows the fingers and thumb to conform around the shape of various objects, creating a secure grip. As well, the fingers and thumb are rubber-tipped to help grasp smaller objects. The prosthesis has an adjustable ball-and-socket wrist, to orient the hand to various postures. The wrist is easy and intuitive to use and gives the amputee ability to perform many different tasks. Since all people are unique, we use 3D laser scanning to capture the distinctive anatomy of an amputee’s limb, allowing for production of a custom 3D printed limb-socket. This provides a comfortable fit, and allows amputees to wear the device all day to perform their daily living needs.



Most importantly, the Victoria Hand is specifically designed for low-cost production and distribution within the countries where it’s needed. Right now, amputees in Guatemala and Nepal must wait for donated, second-hand parts to receive a prosthesis, sometimes waiting for months. Purchasing new, traditional prosthetic systems from western nations is far too expensive for most people. By producing the Victoria Hand in-country using 3D printing and 3D laser scanning, amputees can receive a prosthesis within days of being measured. This groundbreaking prosthesis solution will improve the quality of life of many thousands of amputees in the developing world.

          

We need your help to provide 100+ amputees with upper-limb prosthetic care in Guatemala and Nepal! In order to do this, we’ve set a $94,000 goal to create the needed infrastructure to deliver this prosthetic care. It includes enough money for the prosthesis materials, the equipment, the training, and the staff resources to fit 100 amputees. Once the Print Centers and Partner Clinics are established in Guatemala and Nepal, they can continue to serve many more additional amputees (beyond the 100) for only $320 each!

         

Your donations will help to:

  • Empower 100 amputees who previously had no prosthesis to achieve a better quality of life
  • Provide 50 amputees in Guatemala, and 50 amputees in Nepal, with a complete 3D printed prosthesis system at no cost to them
  • Establish a Print Center and fund a Partner Clinic in Zacapa, Guatemala
  • Establish a Print Center and fund a Partner Clinic in Kathmandu, Nepal
  • Employ and train regional persons to 3D scan, 3D print, and assemble prostheses
  • Establish the base-infrastructure in these countries, so they can help hundreds more amputees in the future (beyond the 100) for only $320 per system
  • Transfer leading edge technology and skills to developing countries, to help give them new economic opportunities

Any size donation will help make this exciting work a reality!  Choose one of our cool perks, or just donate for some good Kharma! You can also help by:

  • Spreading the word and making some noise through your social network connections!
  • Using the share links beside our video and telling the world!
  • Striking up a conversation with your friends about the need for quality prosthetic care in the developing world!
  • Following us on: Facebook & Twitter!
  • Check out our website at: http://victoriahandproject.com

For more information, keep reading below!

Making 3D printed prosthetics is only half the story. The great challenge is getting them directly to the people who need them. This is where our solution really makes a difference. We have partnered with dedicated and experienced prosthetic care providers, Range of Motion Project (ROMP) in Guatemala, and the Nepal Orthopedic Hospital (NOH) in Nepal. This means we can reach those in need.

Starting with Guatemala and Nepal, a Print Center and Partner Clinic will be created in each country. It works like this: VHP establishes a 3D Print Center, equipping it with all the technology and tools necessary to make 3D printed prosthetics. VHP will also employ and train a full-time 3D printing technician from the local community. Our clinical partners provide the clinic space and staff, the clinical fitting expertise, and local care networks. VHP funds the equivalent of one half-time clinician – helping to increase clinic capacity – and provides ongoing technical support to both the print center and the clinic. 

Amputees in need of a prosthesis will approach the clinic first. A professionally trained prosthetist will greet and register them, assess their needs, and cast a plaster impression of their limb. The plaster mold impression along with the amputee’s measurements, are sent to the Print Center where the technician scans the mold using a 3D laser scanner. They then 3D print the prosthesis parts, assemble them, and deliver the completed prosthesis back to the clinic. The clinician fits the amputee, and teaches them to use their new 3D printed prosthesis system. In about one week, an amputee gets a device to help improve their quality of life! Our solution supports local economies, provides training, and transfers exciting technology to developing countries.

There is nothing more important than the quality of the prosthetic device and the care that each amputee receives. We are proud to partner with skilled clinicians to have our prosthetic professionally fit to amputees.

“Amputees are not disabled by a missing limb, but by a missing prosthesis.” - ROMP

Established in 2005 by David Krupa, Eric Neufeld, and headed by Patrick Mathay, ROMP supplies prosthetic and orthotic care to people who would not otherwise have access in the United States, Mexico, Ecuador, and Guatemala.  ROMP realizes that prosthetics are devices of empowerment and employs a strategy of clinical care, local investment, and advocacy. (www.rompglobal.org)

Established in 1998, the Nepal Orthopedic Hospital (NOH) provides quality orthopaedic care at an affordable price.  In a country with no health insurance system NOH is committed to providing charitable care to those who can least afford it.  During the continuing aftermath of the 2015 Nepal earthquake, NOH has treated all patients free of cost.

Presently, millions of people in developing countries do not have access to prosthetic care because of economic status and limited availability of components.

The Victoria Hand Project team and our Clinical Partners believe that all people should have access to prosthetic care regardless of their ability to pay. This crowdfunding campaign will provide enough resources to produce and fit 100 amputees with a complete prosthesis system free of charge.  Beyond these 100 amputees, we are exploring new ways to fund the $320/amputee amount needed for additional prostheses. All efforts will be made to serve every amputee through our Print Centers and Partner Clinics, regardless of their ability to pay.

Donations like yours will help to provide the prosthetic care infrastructure needed in developing nations. Equally important is working towards a sustainable care model. Our sustainability model proposes that the 3D printing and scanning equipment be used for revenue generation during off-hours, since it has numerous external applications. Local community users will be taught valuable 3D printing and 3D scanning skills so that they can produce parts for the repair of equipment, and provide training for local schools and colleges.

We want to be transparent about how your funds will be spent.  Our $94,000 campaign goal has been allocated to maximize the impact of your donations.

It’s important to us that the majority of your donations go to actually helping people in need. For any donations involving physical perks, no more than 10% of your donation will go towards that perk.  If you choose donations without physical perks, you have provided more money to help amputees get the prosthetic care they need.

 The more money you donate, the more amputees we can help. If we achieve our target funding goal, for every additional $320 raised, one additional amputee will receive full prosthetic care. This would allow us to serve more than the 100 amputees! Beyond Guatemala and Nepal, the Victoria Hand Project is actively working to expand to other countries. We aim to soon establish service in Cambodia. More information can be found on our website: www.victoriahandproject.com

We are a dedicated team of engineers, designers, and volunteers based in Victoria, Canada, at the University of Victoria. The Victoria Hand Project is a not-for-profit organization with a mission to provide upper-limb prostheses to people in the developing world. The Victoria Hand prosthesis is based on the original Toronto Bloorview-Macmillan (TBM) Hand prosthesis design of 2001.

Nick Dechev, Ph.D, P.Eng, is Professor and Director of the Biomedical Engineering Program at the University of Victoria. He is the designer of the original TBM Hand, and leader of the Victoria Hand Project team.

Josh Coutts, B.Eng received his mechanical engineering degree from the University of Victoria in 2014. He is the lead designer of the Victoria Hand Prosthesis, and lead for the Guatemala deployment team.

Pranay Shrestha, B.Eng, received his mechanical engineering degree from the University of Victoria in 2015. He is the designer of the prosthesis wrist, and lead of the Nepal deployment team.

Saeedul Alam, B. Eng, received his electrical engineering degree in 2015.
Dirk Brussow is a 4th-year mechanical engineering student.
Andrea Chan is high school student.
Kalonica Christie is a 4th-year mechanical engineering student.
Richard Knowlton, B.Eng, received his mechanical engineering degree in 2014.
Alastair Kuzmick is a 4th-year biomedical engineering student.
Angela MacDonald is a 4th-year mechanical engineering student.
Michael Peirone is a 4th-year biomedical engineering student.
Michael Richards, B.Sc. has a degree in kinesiology and is now studying engineering.
Pranav Shreshta, B.Eng, received his mechanical engineering degree in 2015.
Kelly Stegman, Ph.D., is a post-doctoral fellow in mechanical engineering.
Matt Treble is a high school student.
Sukhpreet Singh is a 2nd-year biomedical engineering student.
Victoria Wheatley is a 2nd-year mechanical engineering student.

We are grateful to the Sponsors and Funding Organizations that supported the research and development, that has helped us get this far!  Thank you to:

The University of Victoria, for fostering an open, creative environment for learning and development, through its pool of talented students, volunteers, research laboratories, and research services staff! In addition, thank you for funding various aspects of this work.

Grand Challenges Canada, for awarding a $112,000 dollar grant in 2014 to Prof. N. Dechev to conduct the initial design and development of the 3D printed prosthesis, and to facilitate our research trials in Guatemala and Nepal.  (http://www.grandchallenges.ca/grantee-stars/063…).

National Science and Engineering Research Council (NSERC), for the Discovery Grant program which provided the seed funding to initiate this project years ago! As well, the NSERC USRA program for funding undergraduate engineering students for this project.

Canada Foundation for Innovation (CFI), for the provision of engineering computing equipment and software that facilitated this research.

CMC Microsystems for the provision of engineering CAD software tools that facilitated this research.

Check out our website  http://victoriahandproject.com  to find out more

Thank you!

The Victoria Hand Project Team.

We are proud to partner with skilled clinicians to have our prosthetic professionally fit to amputees.
“Amputees are not disabled by a missing limb, but by a missing prosthesis.” - ROMP
Established in 2005 by David Krupa, Eric Neufeld, and headed by Patrick Mathay, ROMP supplies prosthetic and orthotic care to people who would not otherwise have access in the United States, Mexico, Ecuador, and Guatemala.  ROMP realizes that prosthetics are devices of empowerment and employs a strategy of clinical care, local investment, and advocacy. (www.rompglobal.org)
Established in 1998, the Nepal Orthopedic Hospital (NOH) provides quality orthopaedic care at an affordable price.  In a country with no health insurance system NOH is committed to providing charitable care to those who can least afford it.  During the continuing aftermath of the 2015 Nepal earthquake, NOH has treated all patients free of cost.
Presently, millions of people in developing countries do not have access to prosthetic care because of economic status and limited availability of components.

The Victoria Hand Project team and our Clinical Partners believe that all people should have access to prosthetic care regardless of their ability to pay. This crowdfunding campaign will provide enough resources to produce and fit 100 amputees with a complete prosthesis system free of charge.  Beyond these 100 amputees, we are exploring new ways to fund the $320/amputee amount needed for additional prostheses. All efforts will be made to serve every amputee through our Print Centers and Partner Clinics, regardless of their ability to pay.
Donations like yours will help to provide the prosthetic care infrastructure needed in developing nations. Equally important is working towards a sustainable care model. Our sustainability model proposes that the 3D printing and scanning equipment be used for revenue generation during off-hours, since it has numerous external applications. Local community users will be taught valuable 3D printing and 3D scanning skills so that they can produce parts for the repair of equipment, and provide training for local schools and colleges.
We want to be transparent about how your funds will
be spent.  Our $94,000 campaign goal has
been allocated to maximize the impact of your donations.





It’s important to us that the majority of your donations go to actually helping people in need. For any donations involving physical perks, no more than 10% of your donation will go towards that perk.  If you choose donations without physical perks, you have provided more money to help amputees get the prosthetic care they need.







 The more money you donate, the more amputees we can help. If we achieve our target funding goal, for every additional $320 raised, one additional amputee will receive full prosthetic care. This would allow us to serve more than the 100 amputees! Beyond Guatemala and Nepal, the Victoria Hand Project is actively working to expand to other countries. We aim to soon establish service in Cambodia. More information can be found on our website: www.victoriahandproject.com

We are a dedicated team of engineers, designers, and volunteers based in Victoria, Canada, at the University of Victoria. The Victoria Hand Project is a not-for-profit organization with a mission to provide upper-limb prostheses to people in the developing world. The Victoria Hand prosthesis is based on the original Toronto Bloorview-Macmillan (TBM) Hand prosthesis design of 2001.


Nick Dechev, Ph.D, P.Eng, is Professor and
Director of the Biomedical Engineering Program at the University of Victoria.
He is the designer of the original TBM Hand, and leader of the Victoria Hand
Project team.

Josh Coutts, B.Eng received his mechanical
engineering degree from the University of Victoria in 2014. He is the lead
designer of the Victoria Hand Prosthesis, and lead for the Guatemala deployment
team.

Pranay Shrestha, B.Eng, received his mechanical
engineering degree from the University of Victoria in 2015. He is the designer
of the prosthesis wrist, and lead of the Nepal deployment team.
Saeedul Alam, B. Eng, received his electrical engineering degree in 2015.Dirk Brussow is a 4th-year mechanical engineering student.Andrea Chan is high school student.Kalonica Christie is a 4th-year mechanical engineering student.Richard Knowlton, B.Eng, received his mechanical engineering degree in 2014.Alastair Kuzmick is a 4th-year biomedical engineering student.Angela MacDonald is a 4th-year mechanical engineering student.Michael Peirone is a 4th-year biomedical engineering student.Michael Richards, B.Sc. has a degree in kinesiology and is now studying engineering.Pranav Shreshta, B.Eng, received his mechanical engineering degree in 2015.Kelly Stegman, Ph.D., is a post-doctoral fellow in mechanical engineering.Matt Treble is a high school student.Sukhpreet Singh is a 2nd-year biomedical engineering student.Victoria Wheatley is a 2nd-year mechanical engineering student.


We are grateful to the Sponsors and Funding Organizations that supported the research and development, that has helped us get this far!  Thank you to:


The University of Victoria, for fostering an
open, creative environment for learning and development, through its pool of
talented students, volunteers, research laboratories, and research services
staff! In addition, thank you for funding various aspects of this work.


Grand Challenges Canada, for awarding a $112,000 dollar grant in 2014 to Prof. N. Dechev to conduct the initial design and development of the 3D printed prosthesis, and to facilitate our research trials in Guatemala and Nepal.  (http://www.grandchallenges.ca/grantee-stars/063…).


National
Science and Engineering Research Council (NSERC), for the Discovery Grant
program which provided the seed funding to initiate this project years ago! As
well, the NSERC USRA program for funding undergraduate engineering students for
this project.


Canada
Foundation for Innovation (CFI), for the provision of engineering computing
equipment and software that facilitated this research.

CMC Microsystems for the provision of engineering CAD software tools that facilitated this research.





Check out our website  http://victoriahandproject.com  to find out more
Thank you!
The Victoria Hand Project Team.

story:
Hi,

My name is Allison, I am a total Techie (Co-Founder and Founder). I am really into educational technology because it is the future of the students learning! It is part of my mission to show students everyday the positive life path they "can" choose to take through education.
    When I mentioned to the students that we could start a "fundraiser" for getting more technology in the classroom and supplies, they quickly commented, "Come on, no one cares!" I want to desperately prove them wrong. By you donating even as little as $1 to our campaign it will all add up, and we will show these young men the world cares. If we raise more than our goal of $5000 we will donate the money to a our favorite charity that gives low income schools the technology they need.
    We are raising money for 5 iPads, one classroom computer, and a few big white dry erase boards for ESL Science learners, we want to spread out 5 iPad stations around the room for interactive labs, and group activities. Students could be dissecting frogs via iPads interactively, chatting it up with educational comments on Edmodo or Google Classroom, writing amazing Sci-Fi stories on Storybird, and then jump over to competing against teams on Kahoot. 
    Let us truly prepare them for their bright futures. Please help us to show them we all believe in them and their success.
Thank you,
 Allison

story:
About Me

My name is Jean-Marc Mercy. I am the CEO and co-founder of the Bridge Initiative (www.thebridge-initiative.org), a social enterprise that promotes volunteerism and social entrepreneurship as pathways to decent employment of young people. The Bridge Initiative is based in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo.

Context

We want to make a difference in the life of unemployed young people in Kinshasa in the next six months. These young people have high potential and are very dynamic, yet they are not given the opportunity to deploy their potential and be actors of the social and economic development of their community. We believe that every young woman and man in every corner of the DRC deserves to be given an opportunity to learn new skills that will prepare them to enter the 21st century workplace. It is estimated that more than 7 million young women and men aged 18-24 in DRC are either jobless or underemployed. This has to change. In order to boost the economic and social development of Congo through its youth by 2030, after more than 20 years of war, it is important that we start acting NOW. The contribution that we make, regardless of its size, will always make a difference. The Bridge Initiative promotes volunteerism and social entrepreneurship as pathways for youth employment.  We harness the power of social innovation to reduce youth unemployment in DRC by building the capacity of young people and placing them on volunteer assignments for social impact.

The Need

More than 80% of universities and schools in Congo lack adequate career services to link students to potential employers. The priority of the Bridge Project right now is to partner with universities and schools in order to prepare students as well as to answer to the immediate needs of youth who are still in school, those who finish high school and want to increase their skills and experience through volunteerism, social entrepreneurship and access to mentors, before they decide to continue their studies at higher education, on one hand, and those who have recently graduated from university and are still struggling to find a decent job, on the other hand. These two categories of youth have the potential to actively participate to the social and economic development of their community, but they lack the skills, experience and opportunity. There is a need to be fulfilled. There is a gap to be filled. There is a Bridge to be built in order to fill the skills and opportunity gap, and the Bridge Initiative is doing just that: trying to fill the skills and opportunity gap.

Our Solution

What we’ve done so far: Since last year we are making a difference in young people’s lives through our career development center by increasing their skills and experience through our career readiness workshops and upcoming volunteer opportunities for young people. In just a few months since the official launch of the Bridge Initiative, we have raised awareness on volunteerism and social entrepreneurship in Kinshasa, recruited more than 50 young people aged 18-30, and now we are helping them to prepare and be ready for a meaningful career in the next two years. We have also talked to potential partner organisations that have accepted to host these young people on stipend-based volunteer assignments after the career readiness workshops, in order to give them the opportunity to increase their experience and employability. We want to reach more young people in the next six months and make a higher impact.

What we hope to do in the next six months: We hope to introduce our curriculum in one of the largest universities in Kinshasa and one high school, namely the Université Catholique au Congo, and the Samuel Levi School, in order to reach more high school and university students. We also want to start a youth café where young people will have networking opportunities with mentors and potential employers. A big screen will be placed in the youth café, and young people will have the opportunity to watch relevant Massive Online Open Courses (MOOCs) while having a drink or eating something.

What we need

We need 15,000$ to change the lives of youth in universities and schools by:

  • Increasing the experience and employability of 100 more young people in Kinshasa through skills development and volunteer opportunities.

  • Increasing access for youths to mentors to foster entrepreneurship and career skills;

  • Increasing access for youths to the labor market information, mentors and career resources.

We are incredibly cost-effective. Our administrative costs are only 5%. All of our staff are volunteers. Besides, our project implementation costs are already covered by our donors. Every dollar you give will be used for scaling up our initiative and printing more career readiness workshop materials. The money will also contribute to youth volunteer stipends during their placement.

What difference your contribution will make

We are building workshop materials and presentations that our 50 young people and mentors like, and we need your help to bring our career readiness workshops to a school and a university in Kinshasa in order to reach  more young people in the next six months. We believe that our project will be successful and will have an impact nationwide. The Bridge Initiative was recognized at the 10th Annual Meeting of the Clinton Global Initiative in New York  as one of the 7 winning ideas of the Youth Employment Challenge that was launched on OpenIdeo (www.openideo.com). Your support will provide in-person training for mentors and university teachers and allow them to add our career readiness workshops to the course schedule.

story:
The Education of Arafa and the Sinai Scholars Program, Babati, Tanzania

When Arafa's father Jumanne gave permission for Arafa to leave her village in Tanzania and travel to the United States, he told her "be like an open door for other girls to pass through." Arafa - only 13 years old then, has worked hard, and is indeed living up to that blessing and challenge. She is now in ninth grade and on track to graduate with her class in 2018. We need help to keep the door open for Arafa and open doors for girls to get quality secondary education in Tanzania.  THIS FUNDRAISER WILL BE THE ONLY ONE FOR ARAFA AND THE SINAI SCHOLARS PROGRAM TO REACH THE END OF THEIR HIGH SCHOOL - end of 2018!

This November, 2013 picture is at the doorway of Arafa's home in Babati, next to the Sinai school.  I am speaking with Arafa, her mother Tatu and father Jumanne are in the doorway (holding on to her 2 year old brother Omari), and a Hawthorne Valley student Ali Reinhold is kneeling next to Arafa's sister, Sabrina (who is now a 1st grader at Sinai school).  On this trip, Arafa was Skype interviewed by the Hawthorne Valley School and a formal acceptance letter was sent the next day.

Arafa's Commitment to You - In Her Own Words

I promise to study hard and to be kind.  I will stay grateful every day.  I miss home but I need this chance.  I want this chance and know one day I'm gong to change the world.

My husband and I founded WaterPowerPeace, a sister school initiative that connects schools and students in the United States with schools in Tanzania.  We launched the program by building a playground that generates power, able to pump clean water and provide lights and charging ability for a school in the developing world.  I met Arafa in 2008 when she was 7 years old, a student at the Sinai School Primary School, in Babati, Tanzania. She became my daughter Grace's pen pal.

On our first visit to Sinai school, the "round trip" to the nearest water source was over one mile - it didn't have a sanitary seal, flooded and was shared by many users.  The children ages 4 - 13, lost hours of class time walking for water each day.  The school didn't have electricity, kindergarten classroom, teacher training, gardens or books.  We selected the Sinai school for our pilot program because of kids like Arafa - the 900 Sinai school students had something special - curiosity, problem solving, joy, and a love of school.  The Sinai school happened to have a devoted principal, Mr. Walter, involved parents and dedicated teachers.  They lacked resources but were rich in the qualities we felt mattered: trust, integrity, work ethic and optimism.  

I have never heard a Sinai student say, "I don't want to go to school today" and we knew that our kids could learn a lot from this culture, these kids and this community.  It has always been our philosophy that we are not "helping" them but we are enriching each other - building bridges through a shared purpose and our priority remains Water First, then Power (in the form of electricity, playground, solar or simply education), then Peace follows (in the form of friendship, love and joy).

My husband John meeting Arafa for the first time in 2008 at the Sinai Primary School in Babati, Tanzania.   At this point, these students had never encountered an English speaking person from America!

In our first year of the sister school model curriculum, the students at Woodland Hill Montessori School working with the students from the Sinai school in Tanzania created a movie, art exhibit, photography exhibit and held a ten item auction.  The model was a success and the 2009 Earth Day exhibit raised enough money for us get water for the school, but also donate books, build a library, hire a kindergarten teacher, support English lessons for the teachers and more.  

Please take the time to view the original movies created by these pioneers.  Links below and feel free to share them - several of the student movies have since won awards and one 14 year old American student won a prestigious National Geographic award for his photo of a Sinai school student taken in 2012 while he volunteered on a summer project trip.

THE WATER PROJECT MOVIE 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ti5i0j0tRnQ

On our third trip to Babati in 2009, we brought 5 middle school age students from Woodland Hill Montessori School in East Greenbush, New York and installed the first pump to bring water to the Sinai school. One of those students, Ali Reinhold, returned to Babati in 2012 - this time with 18 students from the Capital Region.  The 2012 projects included a drip irrigation system, a new library, an art and movie room, computer lab and lessons, reading and spelling programs.  A garden was planted to sustain the lunch program.  By the end of 2012, the Sinai school was unrecognizable and its progress was reflected in what mattered most, the students' grades and future educational opportunities and connected communities. 

This photo from 2009 shows Sherrie Clune, an upper elementary teacher we sponsored (one of four) to visit the Sinai school and gather information to bring back and inspire their students to undertake "the Water Project."   Working with the students (Arafa pictured) we renovated several classrooms, installed a hand washing station and conducted a geographical survey to find suitable water source.

We have sponsored teachers from Sinai school to visit the United States in 2009 and 2011.  During one of those visits, the Hawthorne Valley School offered a scholarship to a deserving Sinai school student. Ali Reinhold, a senior at Hawthorne Valley, spearheaded a campaign to bring Arafa to the United States and we helped make that happen. Arafa successfully completed 8th grade and is now a thriving ninth grader. 

Ali Reinhold, now a college freshman at Wells, travelled to Tanzania in 2009 with the first middle school volunteer trip.  A true ambassador for girls education, she has returned four more times, and spearheaded a campaign to help bring Arafa to study in America on a full scholarship at Hawthorne Valley Waldorf School.
In Ali's words:

When I first visited the Sinai School at the age of thirteen, I immediately knew that my life was going to change. Little did I know how much. I have now traveled to Babati five times and, throughout these journeys, I have gained a little sister in Arafa, an extended family on the other side of the world, and a passion for empowerment through education. Arafa has truly inspired so many people, both in the US and in Tanzania. I am so thankful that she is part of my life, and to all of the people who have made made it possible thus far. I have grown to care so much for her and all of the students at the Sinai School, and I want opportunities (like those of the scholarships) to remain possible.

If you would like to see how this all transpired, please click the link below and spend a few minutes watching this video I compiled to document the process: https://youtu.be/_8W3x2zc8H4

Arafa pictured here at her 8th Grade Graduation with her first tutor, Kevin Wade, who spent over four months in Tanzania to prepare Arafa for her visa and to travel, and spent her first summer vacation to visit her family in Babati so Arafa didn't lose her progress on learning English.

In connection with Arafa's scholarship, we began a Sinai scholars program so that the top girl and boy of each class can attend private secondary eduction. Ten other children receive bicycles, allowing them to get to the secondary school which is over 10 kilometers away.  The kids know that beginning year 5, their grades are being counted for these awards and we push them to grab the brass ring - an education!

Arafa not only dreams of graduating High School here in the United States, she is aiming for University and Law School! It's her dream to empower girls from her village, her country, and here in the United States to dream big and start small, study hard, and get an education.  

Arafa graduated 8th grade and is currently getting all As and B+ during her 9th grade.  Pictured below - a very proud community celebrates her 8th grade graduation last June.


What Your Donated Funds Will Cover:

1st Priority:  School Fees

Hawthorne Valley School donated a five year scholarship to Arafa, allowing her to complete eighth grade and four years of High School.  Arafa's school fees for High School are $2,500 per year. (total $10,000).  

2nd Priority:  Summer School and Tutoring

Although Arafa's English improves everyday, she needs help to fill some gaps in her primarily education and improve her English.  She now understands and speaks fluently, but needs tutoring and summer programs to assist her English skills.  We'd also like to hire a computer and math tutor.  $2,000 per year. (total $8,000)

3rd Priority:  Arafa's Direct Expenses 

When Arafa came to upstate New York, she'd never owned a winter coat or a textbook.  Arafa loves sports and is a talented athlete, member of the soccer team and interested in swimming, dance and theater.  She also calls home to her family every Sunday. Her current host family generously provides room and board and more importantly their love and support.  $2,000 per year. (total $6,000)

4th Priority: Educating Girls, Inspiring Excellence

Sinai Scholars - We've been working with the Sinai school for over seven years and the selection of one student to study in the New York was balanced with the unmet needs of all children graduating.  There are approximately 100 Sinai students each year who graduate 7th grade and can't afford secondary school or lack access to quality secondary education.  Working with community leaders, we put in place selection criteria to choose one boy and one girl to attend a private school in Tanzania - cost $1,000 per year (including room and board).    At full strength, the program requites $9,000 per year.  (total for 2 years - $18,000)

5th Priority: Bicycles for Babati Secondary Scholars

Sinai Scholars - A program inspired by our daughter Grace, who saved her change for one year to help Arafa.  This was enough to fund 10 bicycles for the graduating 7th year primary students (12-13 years old).  The public secondary school is located over ten kilometers away, without water or electricity.  The bicycle program provides transportation, and inspiration for the the three years prior to graduation for the students to study and perform.  Many students, especially girls end their education at age 13 because it is difficult to get to school.  This helps. $800 per year (total $2,400).

6th Priority:  Arafa's Travel to be Home for Ramadan 

We don't let Arafa travel alone, but will volunteer our time and expenses, including our airfare to accompany her.  The average airfare to Tanzania is $1,750 in the summer and her village is several hours from the airport.  $2,000 per year (total $8,000).

Always A Priority - Sinai School Girls

There are multiple projects that need support and our goal is to make them sustainable.  The girls are in need of new latrines, washrooms and while the school now has water, solar panels would help reduce the cost of the pump.
Total: $50,400  (will cover programs until 2018)

Funds raised in excess of our goal are needed and we commit to spend them on continued support of Arafa and the Sinai Scholars and in particular, supporting the education of girls.  The Sinai school is in desperate need of new latrines / toilets for the girls as well as books.  We aim to install solar panels to decrease electricity costs next summer.  If at all possible, we'd like to make it possible for all Sinai students to gain access to secondary education.  We remain open to questions and accountable, and welcome volunteers for current and future projects.  Our Commitment to You: Every dollar donated will be put to the use stated here and for the education of Arafa and the children of Babati.  If you'd like to provide us your email, we will send regular updates and keep you informed of the students' and Arafa's progress to graduation from High School and beyond.



Perks Photo Section

Karma - watch the movies and help us spread the word and be sure to check out the gallery for more videos, pictures and updates on the campaign!
